Sunday, March 17th, 1844.  When the following was recorded.  "There is a tide in the affairs of Men," said the proverb, and I think it ebbs and flows with me about as often as that of the sea, although with less regularity.  Ten months ago I opened a modest little bookstore in which, for a time I managed to get a living, but business growing worse and unclear as full and winter set in I was obliged to look about me for something better to do, and on the 10th of January last unclear, in connection with W.Y.D. the "Metropolitan Reading Room and Circulating Library," and have, in consequence, entered more into the world fully and festively than ever before.  We have given four fancy dress balls, which were well attended, and presented an array of beauty and fashion unclear by anything of the kind in New York.  So far our enterprise gives strong hopes of ultimate success.
From this time my notes were kept with such irregularity that I shall continue my Journal in the narative form.

Sunday, March, 12th-During the past week the city and country have been thrown into considerable excitement by the reported appearance of a comet.  The bright light taken for it's tail turns out to be nothing more than unclear light, common at this time of the year, although usually not as brilliant.
Thursday, June 1st-A new era has this day dawned for me-whether for good or evil time only will show. The subjects of all my sketches were veritable characters, and the incident related feels colored just sufficient to make them palatable to the class of readers for whom they were intended.  While I wrote to amuse, however, I endevored to print a moral, and for this reason, and also because they serve to show the bent of my mind at the time in contrast to what it is now, and thus magnify to a greater unclear the grace of God, which in these latter days has brought me out of nature's darkness with the marvelous light of the Gospel, /for this season I say/I feel justified in placing them on record with the rest of my life's experience.
The following sketch, not only shows the "Ruling unclear strong in Death," but the folly and wickedness of giving all up for the things which perish.
Elkanah Dutson was of the tall, lean and lank order of beauty.  His features and his unclear his unclear and his unclear, were all angles; and his business unclear was as sharp as his features. For the next three years we picked up a precarious living by writing for the Newspapers and for the theatre, and by coloring pictures for a magazine.  I wrote three plays for the theatre all of which were accepted, but failed to appear either in consequence of change of management, or the death of the manager.  With my newspaper articles I was more fortunate.  Everything I wrote being published and well paid for.  The sketches of character already transcribed into the Journal were among them.  Many others which were written from memory, and others taking off the events of the days in which they were written, not having been recorded in my note book, are lost to me-two or three only being now in my possession, and which I shall transcribe.  The plays, although considered clever comedies and burlesques, as well as fair literary attainments, I do not now think unclear the time and paper necessary to transcribe them.  Let them go to the dogs.

This he unclear on, accumulating and worshipping money; occasionally giving small sums to those churches and charitable institutions that gave the greatest unclear to their donors, until at length his robust contribution began to give way to the unclear toil, both physical and mental, to which it was subjected; and the warning of this physician obliged him, after a great deal of persuasion and much greater regret, to retire from business.
It had, however, been too long delayed.  unclear had taken fast hold on him and marked him for its victims.  He was called to the bed of death, all his affairs relative to the disposition of his property were supposed, by his family, to be properly arranged, and they endeavored to direct his mind and heart to things above.  Something, however, seemed to annoy him, for he was restless and discontented.  To all questions put to him on the subject, he would reply that he had forgotten something while making out his will, and all his endeavors to bring it to mind were unavailing, and he could not die contented until he had divorced what it was and disposed of it.  At length, he one day started up in bed suddenly, with an energy

all there set in a head shaped like the Dutch cheeses, with the layer ends a buttery upon each other, and you have a very good picture of Mr. Elkanah Dutson's physiognomy.
Mr. Dutson was in the grocery line, and no man knew better how to make three pommels out of two, or how to make a bargain all on one side, and that side his own.  It was his boast that "none could come it over him."  He always kept unclear qualities of coffee and tea, but they were weighed out of the same drawer or chest; his unclear were exceedingly juicy and, to use his own words, were "consequently much sweeter than the dry, sandy articles of other grocerers"; his liquors possessed a richer color and higher flavor than all others, for he well knew the exact quantity of logwood, burnt sugar, arsenic, copperass?, cream of tatar and other drugs suitable for a given quantity of water, to make a very agreeable and healthy beverage.
Elkanah was what the world calls a man of tact.  He had commenced business with unclear means, in a small way, and in a unclear, gradually enlarging his premises until he had become an extensive wholesale as well as retail merchant. I left a cart, a very good cart, in your care.  Now this cart can never be of any use to my family, but you much.  Now, I wish you to buy that cart, and then I shall be certain that those I leave behind will not be cheated by some unprincipled man, who might want to purchase it."
"Why, Mr. Dutsen, I don't see what possible use I can put it to, seeing that one of the wheels has not a single spoke."
"Oh!  That is easily mended, and then it will be as good as new."
"Not exactly, for one of the bottom boards is gone, and there are no sides to it."
"Those you can soon replace.  Come, now, I'll sell it cheap."
"Well, what shall I give you for it?" inquired Raymond, anxious to please his dying friend, as he saw that the cart was a heavy burden to his mind, even to the expulsion of more serious thoughts.
"You shall have it for thirty dollars," said Dutsen rubbing his thin hands together with pleasure at the thought of unclear of the matter to his satisfaction.
"Thirty dollars!  Why, it is not worth five."
"Five dollars! did you say?  Why, it unclear sixty, and here I offer it for half that sum."
"Yes, cost that thirty years ago."  Old Dutsen became so restless at this remark, and trem

that made those present humble, exclaiming, "I've got it!  I've got it!  send for Mr. Raymond immediately."
Mr. Raymond was his successor in business, a man who, although young, was Mr. Dutsen's complete counterpart in shrewdness.  On his arrival at the sick man's dwelling he was ushered to the bedside, and after the preliminary inquires and answers as to health and circumstances, Mr. Dutsen said;
"I have sent for you, Mr. Raymond, thus hastily as my memory is very much impaired at present, and I was fearful lest the subject on which I wished to see you would escape me before your unclear call.  I feel that it is very necessary that everything concerning my affairs should be attended to before I leave this world, which you must be aware will very soon take place.  Now, I want you to do a favor for me, and then I shall die satisfied."
"Anything in my power, Mr. Dutsen," replied Raymond; "What can I do for you, you need not hesitate to ask."
"Thank you-thank you for the assurance, my friend, for the subject has preyed previously upon my mind."
"You have but to name it, and it shall be done."
"Well, you know when I sold out to you,

There is no melody in it, according to my way of thinking.  There may be music; so there may be in a tin kettle, a cornstalk, or conkshell in skillful hands-in a waterfall, the win, a fox chase, or a locomotive whistle-but is there melody?  That's the question.

Chapter XXI
A Musical Neighborhood  John Rogers Clapton-My First and Last Poem!
At this time I was living in a decidedly musical neighborhood, the Italian Opera had just been introduced into the city, and what I heard and saw inspired the following discriptive article.
They say that "music hath charms to soothe the savage breast, to send a rook," and-and-and split a cabbage head; and I am sure that the delightful plaintive old melodies, and the soul stirring songs of yore wore sufficient to smash the hardest heart, and smooth down the most rugged disposition-make a man fight like a wild cat or clam him into a perfect lamb-work him up into a volcan

It was indeed most heartrenching.  And then, there was her sister, who was down at the piano as soon as she was up, her perfect counterpart; in face, one was so much like both that you could not tell unclear from which.  The airs in Norma? were their delight, and it was Norma? in the morning, Norma? at noon, Norma? in the evening and Norma? at midnight, until I became so sensitive on the subject that the very name on the playbills gave me the unclear whenever they appeared in sight.
On the opposite corner above, Monsieur Baglini has taken up his abode.  He was an invisible gentleman, to me at least, but not a silent one, for he made the walkin ring with the sound of his unclear, as it sent forth the lively notes of "Jenny, is your unclear cake done?"-"Clare de kitchen;" or the more plaintive "Lucy Neal," and kindred pieces; but he must have played them in A flat, for they wore as flat and stale as been long drawn out.  He was a regular bu(r)gler at the business.  I dare say, however, he has got a situation by this time in the Astore Opera House, or is a star in the political zodiac, for no man making such a noise in the world should go unrewarded.
In the house unclear on the same side of the street with my dwelling, Monsieur Violini might be heard at any time of day or night sawing away upon an enormous violoncello, and he is rather a violent fellow with his bow and elbow, I can assure

and forks, popping of champagne corks, jabbering of hairy unclear, and the romping of wild young ladies.
My greatest annoyance was a young lady methinks I hear some ten thousand of our fair readers explain at me "the good for nothing unclear for shame, he ought to be unclear!" and her more elderly sisters, who occupied a large four story house directly opposite, the more unclear of whom I shall designate as Signora Squallini.  She was English by birth, but very desirous of being considered Italian.  She was tall, spare, and not very prepossessing in general appearance, with a voice more like half a dozen cracked steamboat bells than anything else I can think of.  She had the best teacher in the city-an Italian, of course, by name Signor Bagowindi-one who had become rich by his by his extortionate charges; and if in addition, practice can make perfect, she will become the tenth wonder of the world.  It is perfectly charming to hear her at the piano.  She could rattle on the keys so at a regular hard gallop; and then she could rise and fall in the accompanying notes from the finest squeak to the coarsest squall in such a scientific manner.  "She told us, with the greatest ease, her voice went up to all, And proved it till her melodies were maladies to me."

The next house before me is an Italian boarding house, occupied by a host of signors, signoras, and signorettas all, either members of the opera, or teachers of the divine art; at the head of when is the aforesaid Bagowinid.  They never seem to tire of practising their French horns, trombones, pianos, guitars, and their various other instruments of torture; each playing his favorite, regardless of his room mate or neighbor.  It always reminds me of a poor French soldier in the American army, who, having committed an offense against the articles of war, was sentenced to be drummed around the fort with a halter around his neck, to the tune of the "Rogue's March," which was played rather indifferently.  The old fellow seemed to feel the disgrace very keenly, and continually cried out as he tugged at the cord, "Dis-cord is horrible! dis-cord is horrible!

Then Signor Bagowindi owns a beautiful spaniel, and another of the musical gentlemen is possessed of two pointers, and there unclear always take their cue from old Catolini, and as he unclear scope to his voice they answer in the unclear of the trombone.

And can it be doubted that, before my year is out, my heart will be repeatedly melted down to the softest possible consistence, and my mind become completely imbued with the remark once made by Signor Bagowindi, "That there was nothin like Italian music" particularly when accompanied by moustachoes, imperials, and a fire swelling "buzzman" made of cotton wool.

Signorette Cantritini was a most beautiful and voluptuous unclear, and makes a great sensation upon the boards whenever she appears; but her principal forte is in smashing the hearts of her fellow articles of the masculine gentler, for which she was eminently qualified, not only by her grace and beauty, but by all those little acts of a flirt, so effective in Loves battery.
Signor Moustannilini was quite a different being from Signor Bagowindi in every particular.  He was an exquisite of the first water, extravagantly fond of dress, but more of the fair sex.  He spends his money as fast as he receives it, and as much of other people's as he can get hold of-[he finally disappeared one hundred and fifty dollars in debt to his landlady.]
It will not do, however, for me to attempt to describe all the characters that make up this musical neighborhood; all have been seen and admired in their day; all have partaken of the applause and censure of the press and people, drank deep of the unclear bowl of approbation, and nearly all of them have unclear into-a state of unappreciated excellence.

Mr. John Rogers Clayton is with all a very independent 
man.  The opinions of his fellow men are of
very little consequence to him, and the good will of the
press a perfect absurdity.  He thinks that if a man's
talents, accomplishments, his correct bearing and his
exquisite skill in the art - taking himself as the example -
will not bring him customers and fill his
coffers, the favorable opinion of the press would be of
no avail.  I must say, that if all mankind were as
liberal in their patronage of periodical literature
as Mr. John Rogers Clayton, there might be some
foundation for the assertion Mr. John Rogers Clayton
takes three monthly magazines, two weekly papers,
and a daily; but he takes them because they
are sent - for some reason - for services rendered by
his predecessor, I believe - free gratis, for nothing, as
the b'hoys say.  So studiously does he pour over them
from day to day, and so absorbed does he become in
the contemplation of the table of contents on the cover,
that he forgets entirely to cut the leaves.  He however,
does not forget to cut and slash away at his employees
on every suitable occasion, particularly when
they dare to direct enquiries as to the whereabouts
of his friend and predecessor; he is so very fearful,
a middle man, of his being disturbed and distracted
by a press of business.

See what a noble hauteur? there is in every movement-one would not take him to be the son of an American republican that he is, but the scion of some great and ancient home of old England.  See what a blandness there is in his countenance.  Did you ever see a sneer distort those finely chiseled features or a curl of scorn upon those lips, or anger flashing from those mellow eyes?  Perhaps not.  Is he not a nice young gentleman!  But then he can't help if-poor fellow-he was born so.  No man would be so lovely in his disposition if he could-it is all natural, you know; inherent in the heart and, to use a vulgar saying, "what is bred in the bone will come out of the flesh."

Consistency is a great point in the character
of Mr John Rogers Clayton.  For instance, if he has a 
particular idea to carry out, its interference with the
rights of others does not prevent its accomplishment,
for he never seems to even dream of the propriety of consulting
those to be incommoded by the operation; but
let another act in the same manner, and he will immediately
remind the offender that "etiquette should
have prompted you to consult me on the subject before
you took the liberty of doing what you have done."
Had this been done, in ten cases to one, his lordships etiquette
would have prompted him to refuse compliance now,
I would not have you suppose me for a moment, gentle
or rough reader, that such refusal arises out of any
willful or perverse disposition to be found at the bottom
of his heart, or stomach - for Mr John Rogers
Clayton, as I have said before, is, by nature, too amiable,
and that he cannot help; or from any fear of
injury to himself; but his heart is so full of the "milk
of human kindness" that he would be exceedingly
grieved to see a friend commit the same delinquencies
to which he himself is prone, when it is in his
power to prevent it - kind, affectionate creative!!

Then there is my dear sister Marion, and almost equally dear brother Josiah, I wonder if they can remember any unkind words that ever passed between us.  I cannot.

The Lord was now dealing with me in great mercy; for I was very rebellious against Him, and sought every means to banish every right principle from my mind, by nightly visits to the concert saloon, billiard rooms and theatres.  I had made up my mind that it was no longer of any use for me to try to get an honest living, and I threw myself in the way of the depraved characters found in these places expecting that I should receive some proportion from some one of them to join in his iniquity.  I was ready for anything except highway robbery and murder.  I now believe that God withheld their tongues. ing constantly to the mansion on the hill.  When we had gone about two thirds the distance I awoke.  So real appeared the vision that it seemed impossible to reconcile my mind to it as a dream. I did so, and the reunion was a very happy one to me.
It was not long before Abby learned that I had not been to Church for several years, and she used every argument she could think of to induce me to go; but in this I resisted all her importunities and remained obdurate greatly to her sorrow.  Thus my dream was fulfilled.  The house on the hill, in my dream, was the temple of God, and my waking before we reached it foreshadowed her failure in inducing me to go to church.
In the summer of 1855 my dear mother and sister visited me, and spent several weeks at my house.  The visit was a great pleasure to me, but notwithstanding her peadings and my love for her she could prevail upon me to attend church with her but thrice.  I have understood since that she and my dear mother-in-law, Mrs. Putnam, met daily, during this time to pray for the conversion of Anne and myself.

I searched the opening and found it the entrance to a narrows, straight and intensely dark passage.  On the left the solid wall rose far above my reach, and on the right there was a death-like unfathomable abyss, leaving a footpath between of only two feet in width.  I hiked? up a pebble and dropped it into the darkness below, but I could hear no fall.  "this is very strange," I said to myself; "What can it mean?" The place seemed so horrible that, for a moment, I hesitated to proceed; but the two voices were still beside me, one saying, "You will find it worse and worse as you go on; you had better go back;" and the other replying, "You have gone too far to hesitate now-fear nothing."  I plucked up courage and resolved to go on.  I crept cautiously forward feeling my way by the wall, and occasionally thrusting out my foot to the right, to see how near the edge I was.  It seemed to me that I had gone on in this manner about an hour when I came to a large circular space, still very dark; but my eyes had become so accustomed to the darkness that I could see all around it. I became very much straightened in my circumstances-not knowing to day where the meals of the next day were coming from-my occupation being that of coloring and painting photographs.  I daily became more desperate, and was rapidly arriving at the conclusion that honesty was not the best policy after all.  I saw hundreds of men around me who were deeply dyed in every species of iniquity, and who had always enough and to spare; many of them the companions of others who were considered highly respectable in society; and it appeared to me, that, in New York, at least, it was of little consequence how money was obtained, so long as a man had plenty of it he was looked upon with complacency and treated with apparent respect.  Seeing these things daily caused me to repeat to myself frequently-"What is the use of my struggling along in this poverty stricken way, when I might have plenty by acting in concert with those who prey upon the weaknesses and follies of mankind.

was myself the devil was glutting over with such diabolical ferocity preparatory to carting me into the fiery furnace.  He raised the knife to strike, my wife gave a piercing scream and rushed forward, and I awoke trembling in every fibre of my body with the pains of hell, and relieved that it was only a dream.  Of course I looked upon it as the result of the mental excitement I had undergone before lying down but it seemed no less real for all that.
It was broad day-light when I awoke and I arose, took my Bible and read on, trying to find relief from the load of remorse and shame which lay so heavily upon my soul.  I could see no way of escape.  I had sinned away the day of grace.  For such a base, hardened sinner there could be no way of escape.  I was justly condemned and why seek for pardon?  These were my thoughts continually, yet I read on.  I could not take my eyes off the book.  I felt that the way to life was in its pages only, and yet I thought that if I succeeded in discovering it, it would profit me nothing, inasmuch as sentence had already been passed upon me and there could be no reversion.
Every moment I could get was spent in searching the Scripture notwithstanding this conviction?.  Sunday came and,-although my dilapidated wardrobe would, at any other

the Lecture room.  Mr. Dunbar read the first chapter of Luke from the 39th verse and expounded the Scripture. Chapter XXIV
My Baptism - Religious Experiences - The Death of my dear Wife - The Merry God shown to me in a vision
On Friday evening July 18th 1862 I went before the Church in McDougal street and related my Christian experience; but the natural timidity of my mind

and although I felt that peace of God which passeth all understanding, yet, for sometime, I wondered why He had been so meaningful to me; and then I remembered the Scripture, "Not for your sakes do I this, O'house of Israel! but for my holy name's sake," and the thanksgiving arose in my heart, "I thank thee Oh! merciful God that thou caus't do this for thine own sake through the loving sacrifice of thy dear Son, for in me there is nothing that does not deserve perdition.  Oh! what grace to fallen ungrateful man."
Mr. Dunbar called still almost daily to see me, and when I related to him my experience of that night he seemed all aglow with joy and praise, and Oh! how his Christian spirit made me love him.  It was strange to me; however, that he never said anything to me about joining his Church, and one day I asked him some questions on doctrinal points.  He replied, "Search the Scriptures," I replied, "I do taht daily."  Well," said he, "how readest thou?"  I then gave him a synopsis of my faith as it was presented to me in the Bible.  After which he said, "God has wonderfully blessed you in so clear perception of the fundamental doctrines of Christ.  Few men understand them better after ten years experience."  I blessed God for that and

The similitude of the ordinance by which I had renounced the world, and declared my faith in the redeeming grace of Christ, and in His gospel, to the death, burial and resurrection of the Son of God was clear to my mind, and declared so forcibly the true method of admission into the Church, as well as the time and intent, that I wondered why it was that so many good Christians could be so mistaken in their views in regard to it.  How lovely every thing appeared and how my heart went out in love to the children of God!  A new spirit was given me; what I once hated, now I loved, and what I had loved now I hated.  Sins that had been very sweet to me were now gal and wormwood; the pleasures of the world had no longer any charms for me; my delight was, and is, in the sanctuary and service of the Lord.  The most intense desire took possession of my soul that sinners might be converted to God.  The thoughts - "I have served the devil now these forty years, and the residue of my life will be too short to make amends for it, therefore I cannot do too much in honoring and glorifying God," filled my mind continually.
The frailties of my mind, however, were a great cross to me.  I thought I should never have boldness enough to pray or exhort in the meetings.  As soon as the meeting opened I trembled with fear lest I should be called upon, and my

prevented me from doing so as fully as I desire, and many of the circumstance connected with my conversion were omitted; but I have given in this narative all the essential incidents; and these incidents made me a firm believe in the doctrines of election by grace and justification by faith, and subsequent study of the Bible has fully established that belief in its broadest sense; and I may here say that such is the diffidence of my nature that nothing but the grace and power of God could ever have induced me to stand up before the congregation to declare what the Lord had done for my soul.
On Sabbath day, July 27th I had the blessed privilege of being buried with Christian baptism, in the only way commanded by Scripture.  It was the happiest day of my life.  When I found peace in believing and felt that Christ was mine and I was His, I thought a more perfect state of happiness could not be enjoyed by man; but as I came up out of the water that day my whole soul was filled with the love of Christ and gratitude to God; there was an inward exquisite joy that no mortal language can express; the whole place was radiant with the presence of the blessed Saviour, and I felt bound to Him by enduring chords of love and mercy.

was deficient.  I had not that trust in all the promises of the Lord necessary to sustain me in every hour of need, and I prayed secretly for an increase of this blessed grace.  I prayed until I felt that all my help must come from God, and since that time I never have risen to pray from a sense of duty alone - unless I am specially called upon - but only when I feel the spirit of prayer upon me; yet I often resist this spirit and do not pray when I should.  Oh! how true the words of St. Paul - "For the good that I would, I do not; but the evil which I would not, that I do." The lord has given me a great desire to be diligent, faithful and zealous as a laborer in His vineyard, but I am so lamentably deficient in all these respects that the less I say about them the better.  I love the sanctuary of the Lord and its services. Almost immediately after my conversion and acceptance in the Beloved I travailed in my soul for the conversion of my only

heart sank within me because of the desire to testify for Jesus, and my utter inability to do so.  Frequently I essayed to rise, but my heart and limbs quaked so that I could not stand.  Here I was in trouble again; and the devil was ready with his suggestions.  The Spirit would say to me, "now is your opportunity;" and Satan would add, "to make a fool of yourself.  What can you say with your miserable stammering tongue that can please God, or edify His people;" and my tongue was tied.  I began to despond, and Satan was ever near to fill my mind with doubts of my conversion being nothing more than the effects of a disordered imagination.  But God did not permit me to remain long in this fearful state.  For several evenings our beloved Pastor had given pretty strong hints that he expected to hear from me, yet the state of my mind caused me to resist his kind appeals.  One evening he suddenly called upon me to lead in prayer.  I felt as if I should sink into the floor; but I never was one to disobey the orders of my superior officers - humanly speaking - so I arose, praying as I did so, "Lord, help me," and addressed the throne of grace; and sat down again with an overpowering sense of my own weakness, and humbled in the dust.  God and the brethren alone know how I prayed.  But this effort showed me, in a measure, where I

ed work.  All I care to live for now is, that I may glorify God in walk and conversation, in every good word and work; and be the humble means, in His hands, of winning souls to Christ; but, the Lord's will in this, as in all other things, be done.
During these years of grace the Lord prospered me in temporal as well as in spiritual affairs and caused me to rejoice in the liquidation of many debts which hung over me to trouble me, although they were, what is termed, outlawed.  With all these blessings the Lord was pleased to bring affliction, and on the 25th of November 1865 He called my dear wife from this world.  I was so stunned by this blow, it came upon me so suddenly, that it was months before I could fully realize my loss, or recover peace.
She had been taken ill in July previous, and after a severe season of billious? fever and jaundice, recovered; but in the middle of October she began to lose strength from some unknown cause, and was soon confined to her room.  She, however, complained very little, and day after day led me to believe that she was getting better.  The physician also gave it as his opinion that she would recover.  I therefore felt no apprehensions.  Two weeks previous to her death she was taken with hermorage? - apparently from the bowels, and three days after the doctor informed me, that he was puzzled in regard

living brother - residing at the west - who was an avowed Universalist.  For him my prayers were unceasing, and I accompanied these prayers to God by letters of exhortation and doctrine to him.  During a revival a few months later God showed mercy to him and brought him into the sheepfold, and he now rejoices in Christ, another monument of the power and goodness of God in subdoing? the stubborn heart of man to himself.  Copies of these letters I have bound in a book and maybe read as giving the reasons for the truth that is in me, and as showing the groundwork of my faith.
Since the beginning of my religious life all my opportunities have been devoted to the study of the Bible, and it has been, together with the other blessed privileges of heavenly communion, the delight of my soul.  Many of my thoughts on various portions of Scripture have been committed to writing, either in the form of sermons, or lessons for my Sunday School scholars.  If, when the Lord takes me to himself, or at any time, they shall be the means of leading one soul to Christ, the Lord be praised.  I have desired, and hoped, that God would inspire me with the ability to preach, as well as write, these sermons; for it I could do the former I would willingly relinquish every earthly tie, and every prospect of worldly gain and devote the rest of my life to the bless

The thought that she must have awoke during the night and called to me, and I not know it. her face wore a beautifully serene aspect.  I felt happy that God was dealing so gently with her in her last moments, which I believe was in direct answer to prayer.  During the time she was suffering the most severely, I asked a brother of our church to join me in prayer for the abatement of the pain, and that, if it was God's pleasure to take her to himself, He would not let her thus suffer.  We knelt down together and both prayed for her life if it were possible; but if not, that she might be relieved from pain.  Before we had concluded her groans had ceased, and from that moment she showed no signs that she suffered any.
At twenty six minutes, past one o'clock on Saturday morning I could not refrain longer from speaking to her, and, as preliminary to other questions (to learn if she were still conscious) I asked her if she loved me.  First her bosom heaved with convulsive effort, then she raised her head partially from the pillow, and by a violent struggle succeeded in replying quite audibly, "Yes."  Her head fell back; she breathed four times at long intervals, and expire at precisely half-past one o'clock.  The exertion to answer me was too much for her strength.  Oh! how I wished that I had asked her if she had found peace in the love of Christ.  Why did I ask that ques

cover from - in my hours of solitude it is ever recurring to my mind.  She remained speechless and apparently unconscious all day.  About eight o'clock in the evening she moved her hands and fingers as if she desired something - showing that she was now conscious - but, miserably stupid man that I was, I could not understand what she wanted, and it was not until after she was buried that the truth flashed upon my mind that she was asking for pencil and paper.  She could not speak and she wanted to write.  Oh! often I have thought of the blessing I must have lost by my stupidly, but, thank God, I was led to say to her, "my dear wife, I fear that you are going to leave me all alone - God is going to take you from me.  Have you found Jesus precious to your soul?"  She struggled for a moment, and with great effort replied in an earnest, fervent whisper - "Yes, indeed."  None but the true Christian can understand my feelings at that moment.  "Thank God!" was all that I could say; but my heart was overflowing with love, hope and gratitude.  Her effort to answer me appeared to be so painful that I refrained from asking any more questions, although I could restrain my impatience to hear more with great difficulty.  She did not speak again until four minutes before her departure.  She lay perfectly quiet, breathed easily and calmly; and

I was seated in my chair by the table reading my Bible, as usual before going to bed, when my dear wife appeared to me between the table and the door.  She was radiant in the beauty of the days when we first met, and her whole form was enveloped in a halo of heavenly vesture.  Celestial joy and happiness beamed from her lovely face, and the sweet smile with which she was wont to great me - especially in the early days of our married life - when I returned home from my labors, played upon her lips.  Nothing but a change from earth to heavenly immortality could have wrought the perfection of human form in which she appeared to me.  I sprang from my seat, but she made a motion to me not to approach her, at the same time giving me a look full of love and blessedness.  I asked her to speak to me.  She continued silent.  "Oh! do speak to me," I said, "and tell me if you are now happy."  Still she remained silent and smiled upon me with ravishing sweetness.  "Oh! do speak to

tion?  I knew already that she loved me; she had proved that too often for any doubt.  It is one of the mysteries of Providence, and I immediately thought it was because she was not saved; but I have no doubt now.  The truth has been revealed to me since in more ways than one.  I followed her to the grave in Greenwood, on Monday following with a desolate heart.  With few exceptions we lived happily together for twenty nine years; and I loved her ardently and sincerely.  In our differences I have more to reproach myself with than her.  Knowing that she is in a better world I would not recall her, although, if she were now with me, I would not exchange her for any other woman I ever knew.  It was months before I could realize that I should never see her again in this world.  I trust that I was submissive to God's will, but my mourning, at first, was as much in fear of her being lost eternally, as on account of my own bereavement.  My room was desolate without her; but I applied to the Lord and He relieved my distress, and when this relief came I prayed that He would give me some token whereby I might be assured that she was in the arms of Jesus in the realms of the blessed.  He soon sent me to a lady with whom she was intimate; a good Christian lady - who informed me that my dear wife had called to see lately, oftener

not have made the slightest effort to inform them of my true state.  I had often read of persons being buried alive while in this state, but the thought that this might be my case did not trouble me; for I had no doubt that before anyone entered the room I should have departed and gone to the bosom of the blessed Saviour; and this thought gave me such perfect joy and resignation that I folded my hands upon my breast, as they were lying when I awoke, commended my soul to God, and calmly waited for the passage of the dark river.
I know not how long I remained thus; but I was greatly disappointed when I found myself recovering my usual vitality, as I felt that it was far better to depart and be with Jesus.  A delightful sensation of serene happiness followed my recovery, and I fell into a tranquil sleep, from which I awoke late in the morning, in the midst of another dream in which I imagined myself dying during prayer meeting in the arms of our pastor's wife and surrounded by my brethren and sisters in Christ.  It was a very pleasant dream.
During the next year I felt my loss exceedingly and was very lonely, but I looked to the Lord, from whom every blessing flows, for comfort, and He was pleased to give it me in the delights of His sanctuary privileges, in the work of the

Still that heavenly smile, and a gesture of warm affection, but no reply.  "Oh! won't you speak to me!" I exclaimed, and made a step towards her.  Her hand warned me back, and then waved a loving adieu.  "Oh!" I said; "It is too bad that you should leave me without assuring me of your present happiness!"  The hand and arm again appeared through the darkness, and again waved an affectionate adieu.  I sank back in my seat exclaiming, "It is too bad! it is too bad! that you would not make me again happy by assuring me of your present happiness!"  She then appeared to me again in the form of a beautiful butterfly - the emblem of happiness - fluttered joyfully around for a moment and vanished forever.
An inexpressible feeling of thankfulness and gratitude to God, and happiness of soul took possession of my whole being.  I felt assured that she was now in the land of the blessed, enjoying all the fullness of the precious promises of Christ.  I awoke, and found myself perfectly rigid - as cold as ice - and unable to move head, hand or foot.  I felt as if death had taken hold of me. With what money I had saved while in office I commenced the Auction business expecting to be able to prosecute it successfully after the receipt of monies I hoped to derive from Revenue cases I had in Court; half of the proceeds from which would have belonged rightfully to me; but five hundred of this was given to another party by the unjust art of the Commissioner, but without any fault upon the part of the recipient; and from two to three thousand dollars was lost by the carelessness - to say the least - of the U.S. Marshall, in permitting the property, which I had placed in his hands, to be spirited away.  For the want of these funds I could make no progress in the business, and after struggling along until the twentieth of October of this (1867) year, I accepted the agency of a Piano Forte Manufactory, the hand of the Lord seeming to be in it.  In fact, the Auction business was so poor that I made up my mind to leave the city as soon as possible after the first of November unless it improved, or some other business more profitable should present itself.  Another thing also influenced me in this decision, and I presented both cases to the Lord and asked a token of what He would have me to do.  But I must go back a little to tell the whole story.

Chapter XXV
From October 1866 to January 1868. - Out of Office, and in Business. - God's dealings - A Dream - Thoughts and reflections - Incidents and c.
On the first of November 1866 I went out of office.  That rare unclear, Andrew Johnson, acting President of these United States reformed President Lincoln's appointees out of office and his own particular unclear in, and my occupation as tax-gatherer was gone.  I did not regret this, as there was nothing to recommend the position except its unclear advantages, and this was more than counterbalanced by the by the hard and difficult fight which had to be waged continually against vice and fraud, and the liability, at any time of having to meet false accusation and slander.  I tried to do my duty, and if I failed in any respect, or took any wrong means in doing it it must be laid to the charge of want of judgement, or the weaknesses of the old man, and I can only say, may the Lord forgive me.  The peculiar trials of the situation caused me to rejoice rather than regret the loss of my position.

My advances met with a prompt, yet kind repulse.  As in all matters that concern me since my conversion, I laid this before the Lord that I might know His will concerning it.  During on of my prayers asking a blessing on my efforts to gain her love this passage of Scripture came forcibly to my mind, "Trust in the Lord and He will bring it to pass."  It gave me new hope and I resolved to go forward.  I wrote her several notes giving a sincere and full account of my feelings toward her.  The second she answered kindly - almost affectionately - but declining to give any encouragement to hope for a return of my love.
